snip>
> Comparison with WWW is not fair. =A0There is a single shared semant=
ic
> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
>=
 resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
> </snip>
>
> think ab=
out what you say here: that there is a "shared semantic"
> understanding. a=
nd where does this understanding exist? only (and
> solely) in the head of =
humans?
>
> after careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
> =
real-world markers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
> rea=
l world; ones that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
> activat=
ed by humans. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
> are render=
ed by common Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
> in the most ub=
iquitous human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
> HTML.
>
> "Semantic=
 meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
> property is "=
created" by humans when they observe the visual
> "landscape" rendered by =
=A0Web browsers.
>
> Does anyone here want to assert that this "semantic me=
aning" can
> _only_ emerge when humans are *directly* involved in the real-=
time
> interpretation of messages that contain these (or similar) markers?
=

Afaict, there's a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven't seen a
client=
 implementation which demonstrates automated capabilities which
come 'close=
' to that of a human, we're basically talking about the
web's version of a =
Turing Test.

Most of the evidence so far suggests this is the case, althou=
gh I am
not an AI expert.

> Or
> is it possible that humans can "code" age=
nts to have (at least some
> of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and=
 activate the
> "affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?
>
> It is =
my assertion that the latter is the case. I also contend that
> making the =
assumption that this is possible is a key step in advancing
> the art and t=
heory of distributed hypermedia.
>

I think it's an interesting research to=
pic but the complexity of
producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's=
 inevitable that only
a small portion of your client base will behave this =
way (unless you
control them all, in which case your system is not very dis=
tributed!).
So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve your applica=
tion in
a way that caters to the lowest common denominator - undermining th=
e
effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients. This is a big
chall=
enge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of the challenge
of inventi=
ng the designs for such an autonomous hypermedia agent.

Cheers,
Mike
